results.name: A triangle formed like Pascal's triangle, but with factorial(n) on the borders instead of 1.
formula: T(n, k) = T(n-1, k-1) + T(n-1, k) with T(n, 0) = T(n, n) = n!.
mathematica: t = {}; Do[r = {}; Do[If[k == 0||k == n, m = n!, m = t[[n, k]] + t[[n, k + 1]]]; r = AppendTo[r, m], {k, 0, n}]; AppendTo[t, r], {n, 0, 10}]; t = Flatten[t]
program: if k eq 0 or k eq n then return Factorial(n);
[T(n,k): k in [0..n], n in [0..12]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, May 02 2021
def T(n,k): return factorial(n) if (k==0 or k==n) else T(n-1, k-1) + T(n-1, k)
flatten([[T(n,k) for k in (0..n)] for n in (0..12)]) # _G. C. Greubel_, May 02 2021
xref: Cf. similar triangles with t on the borders: A007318 (t = 1), A028326 (t = 2), A051599 (t = prime(n)), A051601 (t = n), A051666 (t = n^2), A108617 (t = fibonacci(n)), A134636 (t = 2n+1), A137688 (t = 2^n), A227075 (t = 3^n).
